name: NPR
text:
Colorado's governor has pardoned the "Balloon Boy" parents, who in 2009 claimed a large balloon had taken their son thousands of feet into the air. 

They pleaded guilty to a few crimes after authorities said it was a hoax.
https://t.co/b0xjjeOgs6

name: NPR
text:
This year's Christmas Eve Mass at St. Peter's Basilica had only 100 or so attendees — all of whom wore masks, except the pope and a small choir. 
 
https://t.co/uYgKv34AGg

name: NPR
text:
New modeling suggests the U.K. coronavirus variant is about 50% more transmissible than previous versions. Scientists don't know why yet — but urge diligence in mask-wearing, hand-washing and social distancing.
https://t.co/JmCYEkqkCb

name: NPR
text: It was just Day 2 of competition for the fledgling NBA season, but it's already off to a bumpy start. After 3 Rockets players returned coronavirus tests that were either positive or inconclusive, their match up with Oklahoma City was postponed. https://t.co/Ow94n0YwKy

name: NPR
text:
RT @reeseoxner: The so-called balloon boy incident captivated television audiences in 2009 as the parents of a 6-year-old named Falcon reported he had been carried away in a large, UFO-like balloon, thousands of feet in the air. 

But he never was in the balloon.

https://t.co/ctKhQuIDa8

name: NPR
text: RT @Lucian_Kim: Putin is counting on Sputnik V to stop the spread of the coronavirus in Russia—but faces widespread reluctance among ordinary Russians to get vaccinated. My report from Moscow: https://t.co/WCMM122Jdw

name: NPR
text:
The Columbus police chief recommended officer Adam Coy be dismissed from the force after he shot and killed a 47-year-old Black man, Andre Maurice Hill, less than 10 seconds after finding him in a garage on Tuesday.
https://t.co/IPIKLJSgdh

name: NPR
text:
"We have no ICU beds," said a chief medical officer at one of LA's largest hospitals. "We are just continually, 24 hours a day, scrambling to move patients around. The flood just continues."
https://t.co/B0XWzRSgGn

name: NPR
text:
Since 2011, this Baltimore duo has donned Santa suits and delivered BBQ and Christmas trees to adorning locals.

Not even a pandemic could stop the holiday tradition.

"A tree and a smile mean more now," Mike Santoro says.
https://t.co/oSo47eXI6z

name: NPR
text:
Since 2011, this Baltimore duo has donned Santa suits and delivered BBQ and Christmas trees to adoring locals.

name: NPR
text: President Trump often takes credit for "unleashing America's scientific genius" in pursuit of a coronavirus vaccine. But immigrants have been involved in every facet of that effort, and people in the industry say U.S. genius depends on global talent. https://t.co/iJ5HlSvUEg

name: NPR
text:
A 60-year-old woman in New Mexico went to a local gynecologist after experiencing pelvic pain and cramping. The doctor did an exam and took a vaginal swab sample for lab testing.

Then the nightmare came.

A $12,386.93 fee.
https://t.co/I4rgaFQV3x

name: NPR
text:
The CDC first recommended Americans wear masks on April 3. 

Prisoners at Louisiana State Penitentiary, known as Angola, didn't get them until June or July, a former inmate says.

Even then, many eschewed them out of fear of being strangled.
https://t.co/epjxQkt1Mk
